questionblock.name: Switch Click Mode
questionblock.text: Enabling this setting reverses the behaviour of the click and SHIFT-click operations. SHIFT-clicking will pick items up into your hand; clicking will put items in your belt or inventory.

questionblock.name: Move as Combat/Use
questionblock.text: Enabling this setting will let you attack things, interact with objects, and open doors by moving to objects with the move keys (WASD by default.)

questionblock.name: Use Autoloot
questionblock.text: Turning on auto-loot lets your character pick up items by stepping on them. You can control which items get picked up by using the auto-loot settings to your right.

questionblock.name: Disable Click-To-Move
questionblock.text: If click-to-move is disabled, the player will not walk anywhere when you click on empty ground. Instead, you must use the movement keys (WASD by default) to maneuver.

questionblock.name: Belt Help
questionblock.text: This is your belt bar. Crossbow ammunition, thrown weapons, and wands must be placed here to be used with a right-click. Other items can also be held in your belt for convenient access. Any slot in your belt with an item can be used by pressing shift and the number of the belt slot.

questionblock.name: Spell Help
questionblock.text: This is your spell and skill bar. Icons representing all spells or skills can be placed here using the [+] button (and are placed automatically upon learning the appropriate spell or skill). To use a spell or skill, left click to select it and you will see the icon placed into the gold active skill slot which is to the left of your spellbar. You can then right click on the dungeon to use the spell or skill on something.

tooltip.name: crushing
tooltip.text: Crushing damage is caused by maces, blunt objects, feet, rocks, and elderly gravy. It is affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: slashing
tooltip.text: Slashing damage is caused when you manage to get the sharp bit of the weapon to cut through the flesh of the other guy. It is affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: blasting
tooltip.text: Blasting damage, first discovered by Alfred Nobel, refers to any damage projected from the quasi-elemental plane of dynamite. It is affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: piercing
tooltip.text: Piercing damage is caused when you manage to get the pointy bit of the weapon to stick into the other guy's flesh. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: conflagratory
tooltip.text: Conflagratory damage is inflicted upon your opponent when you manage to set any part of them on fire. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: hyperborean
tooltip.text: Hyperborean damage is inflicted by frostbite, frost demons, frost weapons, Frost Brand, and frost giants. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: voltaic
tooltip.text: Voltaic damage is any damage of an electrical nature. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: toxic
tooltip.text: Toxic damage is everything icky, nasty, and poisonous. It is often inflicted by tiny Brazilian frogs. The frogs do not like you very much, and we do not recommend strapping them to your equipment. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: righteous
tooltip.text: Righteous damage is inflicted by holy weaponry, really pretty elven maidens, angelic beings, certain sorts of very mystical and holy crystals, and mineral water. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: necromantic
tooltip.text: Necromantic damage is inflicted by necromancy, which usually means that you have a sword that drains life or turns people into zombies or something. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: acidic
tooltip.text: Acidic damage is why you should always be careful when attempting to make a really large baking-soda-and-vinegar volcano. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: putrefying
tooltip.text: Putrefying damage is inflicted by any attacks that cause your opponent's flesh to decay and rot, such as by attacking them with the vegetable crisper in a refrigerator. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: transmutative
tooltip.text: Transmutative damage is inflicted when your attack changes something into something else, like clean white linens into a very large dry-cleaning bill. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: aethereal
tooltip.text: Aethereal damage is inflicted when your attack damages using the power of the stars. We have absolutely nothing funny to say about this, because we take astronomy very seriously. So should you. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: asphyxiative
tooltip.text: Asphyxiative damage is very hard to spell, and is inflicted upon your opponent when your attack suddenly causes them to stop breathing. This is usually accomplished by removing air from the room, and replacing it with gas, cabbage scents, or noxious cologne. It is not affected by your opponent's armour.

tooltip.name: existential
tooltip.text: Existential damage: does it exist or not? We don't know, but your weapon may inflict it on somebody... if they exist. It is not affected by your opponent's armour, if it exists. This tooltip is now going to go off and question its existence, read Heidegger, and weep piteously into a bottle of Dr. Sanin's New-Age Pilsner.

tooltip.name: crushing
tooltip.text: Crushing resistance allows you to successfully resist the impact of large, blunt objects like bricks.

tooltip.name: slashing
tooltip.text: Slashing resistance protects you from attacks with bladed edges. It also helps reduce razor burn.

tooltip.name: blasting
tooltip.text: Blasting resistance lets you go out with a bang.

tooltip.name: piercing
tooltip.text: Piercing resistance allows you to be stung by twenty thousand bees and not feel a thing! (Well, very little.)

tooltip.name: conflagratory
tooltip.text: Conflagratory resistance is very useful if you're a witch, or are likely to be working near witches or other flammable objects. Caution: asbestos armour has been determined by the Dwarven Mountainhomes to cause an increase in lung cancer, beard rot, and Strange Moods.

tooltip.name: hyperborean
tooltip.text: Hyperborean resistance, common amongst the savage Viking hordes, helps you survive even the chilliest of winters or wintery attacks.

tooltip.name: voltaic
tooltip.text: Voltaic resistance is best achieved by strapping frogs to your body. Their tough, thick, insulating hides will help protect you from any electrical encounters. Failing that, we recommend magic rings or something.

tooltip.name: toxic
tooltip.text: Toxic resistance is highly praised by those gourmands wishing to dine on the finest in Goblin cuisine.

tooltip.name: righteous
tooltip.text: Righteous resistance helps protect you from being smote by Divine Powers. It will not, however, protect you from being eaten by bears, as befell the children who mocked the prophet Elisha.

tooltip.name: necromantic
tooltip.text: Necromantic resistance is very useful when dealing with any members of the undead, and the occasional politican.

tooltip.name: acidic
tooltip.text: Acidic resistance is best achieved by covering yourself, head to toe, in baking soda. Failing that, we suggest the adventurer's fallback: magic rings, again.

tooltip.name: putrefying
tooltip.text: Putrefying resistance lets you survive attacks which try to rot your skin off.

tooltip.name: transmutative
tooltip.text: Transmutative resistance helps you resist transmutation. Whatever that is.

tooltip.name: aethereal
tooltip.text: Aethereal resistance protects you from attacks fuelled by the power of the stars, the universe, and the influences of the Celestial Bodies upon your more earthly body. Caution: do not stare directly into the Celestial Aegis.

tooltip.name: asphyxiative
tooltip.text: Asphyxiative resistance: the Heimlich Maneuver of the tenth century.

tooltip.name: existential
tooltip.text: Existential resistance: you think, therefore you resist.

tooltip.name: Burliness
tooltip.text: Burliness. А потом описание на русском. Burliness is the primary attribute of the Warrior and pertains to getting into trouble, hitting one's head on other people, and getting hit by large objects/limbs/pseudopods. It affects life points, melee power, and block chance.

tooltip.name: Sagacity
tooltip.text: Sagacity is the primary attribute of the Wizard, and is mostly about being a know-it-all. It affects mana points and magic power.

tooltip.name: Nimbleness
tooltip.text: Nimbleness is the primary attribute of the Rogue and is the quality of swiftness, grace, and not getting hit by things. It affects dodge chance, sneakiness, enemy dodge reduction, and counter-attack chance. Nimbleness is pretty great.

tooltip.name: Caddishness
tooltip.text: Caddishness is the primary attribute of the Pirate and revolves around not caring about the feelings of others. It affects critical hit and counter-attack chance.

tooltip.name: Savvy
tooltip.text: Savvy is the primary attribute of the Bard and involves being clever while avoiding trouble. It affects magical haywire chance and sneakiness.

tooltip.name: Stubbornness
tooltip.text: Stubbornness is the primary attribute of the Monk and enhances self-righteousness and the ability to ignore mean things other people say about you. It affects magical resistance and block chance.

tooltip.name: Melee Power
tooltip.text: Melee Power affects how hard you hit with your weapons (or feet, if you don't have any). It's also how hard you throw stuff, but not how hard you shoot your crossbow bolts because that wouldn't make sense.

tooltip.name: Critical Chance
tooltip.text: Critical Chance affects how likely you are to land a particularly effective blow in combat, dealing double damage.

tooltip.name: Counter Chance
tooltip.text: Counter Chance affects how likely you are to commit a vindictive act in melee combat by returning an enemy's attack with one of your own.

tooltip.name: Magic Power
tooltip.text: Magic Power affects the power of your spells.

tooltip.name: Haywire Chance
tooltip.text: Haywire Chance affects how likely your spells are to trigger a highly unstable resonance cascade event.

tooltip.name: Magic Resistance
tooltip.text: Magic Resistance affects how intuitively you can (mostly) nullify a magical attack against you.

tooltip.name: Armour Absorption
tooltip.text: Armour Absorption is how good your armor is at standing between you and inevitability. Each point of Armour Absorption removes one point of mundane damage types (eg. crushing, slashing, and blasting).

tooltip.name: Block Chance
tooltip.text: Block Chance affects how likely you are to (mostly) block what you deserve, at least so far as physical attacks go.

tooltip.name: Dodge Chance
tooltip.text: Dodge Chance affects how likely you are to avoid the consequences of your actions and physical attacks.

tooltip.name: Enemy Dodge Reduction
tooltip.text: Enemy Dodge Reduction affects how likely an enemy is to not dodge your attacks. Because heroes never miss - but sometimes their attacks are dodged.

tooltip.name: Sneakiness
tooltip.text: Sneakiness is how good you are at tip-toeing around your problems rather than facing them. Helps with sneaking by enemies, not waking sleeping enemies, and with avoiding traps.

tooltip.name: Visual Sight Radius
tooltip.text: Visual Sight Radius is how far you can see in the dark dungeon.

tooltip.name: Trap Sight Radius
tooltip.text: Trap Sight Radius determines the distance at which you can spot and identify traps.

tooltip.name: Trap Affinity
tooltip.text: Trap Affinity is a rating of your ability to avoid and disarm traps.

tooltip.name: Wandcrafting Level
tooltip.text: This is a rating of how good you are at wandcraft.

tooltip.name: Smithing Level
tooltip.text: This is a rating of how good you are at smithery.

tooltip.name: Alchemy Level
tooltip.text: This is a rating of how good you are at alchemizing.

tooltip.name: Tinkerer Level
tooltip.text: This is a rating of how good you are at tinkering.

tooltip.name: Life Points
tooltip.text: This number shows how not-dead you are. When it hits zero you cease to live. Try not to let this happen.

tooltip.name: Mana Points
tooltip.text: This number shows your capacity to cast magic spells, all of which cost mana to some degree or other.

tooltip.name: Health Regeneration Bonus
tooltip.text: Listen up, this one is tricky: This number is your health regeneration bonus. It is subtracted from the base health regeneration rate to determine the number of steps it takes for you to regenerate one point of health. A higher number is better.

tooltip.name: Mana Regeneration Bonus
tooltip.text: Listen up, this one is tricky: This number is your mana regeneration bonus. It is subtracted from the base mana regeneration rate to determine the number of steps it takes for you to regenerate one point of mana. A higher number is better.

questionblock.text: Почитай это ))) These are your primary statistics. Each one represents a certain primariness.
И это тоже )) To the right are the number of skills you've learned in the category of each Heroic Archetype. For every skill learned, you gain a corresponding Archetype level.

questionblock.name: Horadric Lutefisk Cube
questionblock.text: Before the Lutefisk God, all is fisk to the lut. Place your inedible items into the cube to transform them into possibly even less edible Lutefisk. SHIFT+ALT click them to do so automagically. Skol!

material.text: illudium fosdex, the shaving cream atom

insult.text: from hell's heart, i stab at thee
hang on, i have a cramp
i have a bad feeling about this
i have battled diggles more fearsome than thee
i hope they nerfed your spells
i hope you have a terrible day
i will use your tongue as chewing gum
i'm not even supposed to be here today...
killing me won't bring back your honey!
my therapist says this will be good for me
one more adventurer and i can finally retire
strength in numbers, boys, strength in numbers
thine eyebrows cannot protect thee this time
this was supposed to be my day off
thou art a pimple on the dungeon floor
thou art a troll-whoring sheep buggerer
thy degree in dungeoneering means nothing
we have ways of making you talk
you do know i'm at least five levels higher than you are, right?
you reek of fear and lutefisk
you walk like an undead turkey
your father was a quivering side of man-beef
i'm a nihilist i believe in nothing!

random.text: Dungeons of Dredmor would like to remind you that today is Take Your Daughter to Work Day. This is a perfect time to... oh, never mind.
Maybe you shouldn't have eaten that lutefisk...
Plebs are needed.
Something smells like burning. Mmm, hickory.
Something smells really, really good.
Suddenly you feel like you've forgotten something very important. What was it?
The hollow calls of undead mandrill echo through the dungeon.
The pungent stench of mildew emanates from the wet dungeon walls.
You can't cut back on funding! You will regret this!
You feel a sudden, overpowering sense of regret.
You feel good about yourself.
You have insufficient Vespene gas. Mine more Vespene gas.
You hear chimes in the distance.
You hear haunting moos.
You hear the carousing of the Dwarf Lords.
You hear the howl of a banshee.
You hear the sound of a man trying to remove himself from an Evisceration Chute.
You hear the sound of gurgling pipes.
You hear the thrumming of runes of power.
You narrowly avoid stepping on an olm.
You step on something squishy.
You're doing swell! Give yourself a pat on the back.
You must gather your party before venturing forth.

wizardname.text: Moraivic (not to be confused with Moravic)
Moravic (not to be confused with Moraivic)

wizardspiel.text: Available for parties and bar mitzvahs.
Available for pub crawls and seniors' buffet lunches.
Why yes, our owl is artificial.
Not allowed to do parties anymore.
Magical drycleaning done in the comfort of your own dungeon.

wizardtag.text: Specializing in new and used dimensions.
Prices driven mad by eldritch horrors.
